subject: Some Odds, Some Ends, Some This, Some That
event:
Random musings and nuggets of news, oh my.

I don't follow comics closely these days, but do buy an issue from time to time, and of course I do have still have huge affection for the characters of my lost youth.  So I was puzzled recently when one of my readers emailed me to ask what I thought about what Marvel had done to Spider-Man.  I didn't know what Marvel had done to Spider-Man, but I was curious enough to Google, and pretty soon I found out.  Bloody hell.  I hate this, and judging from the discussions I am seeing on various blogs, I am not alone.  Retconning sucks.  Leave the goddamned continuity ALONE, for chrissakes.  What happened, happened.  Take an old character in a new direction, fine, cool, but don't go back and mess around with the character's past.  It's a breach of trust with your audience, as I see it.  The DC universe has never really recovered from the Crisis on Infinite Earths, despite all the Crises that have followed, and I think the Marvel universe, and Spidey in particular, will be a long time recovering from this decision.  So that's my two cents.  In a nutshell: boo, hiss, shame on you, Marvel.  If I had a rotten tomato, I would throw it.

And here's a promise you can write in blood.  The Wild Cards universe will never be retconned.  What happened happened, and will continue to have happened, no matter what might happen in the future.  

On other fronts, there's a nice new review of HUNTER'S RUN up at http://fantasybookcritic.blogspot.com/2008/01/hunters-run-by-george-r-r-martin.html

The political season is well underway.  I haven't made any political posts here as yet, but be warned, they will be coming.  That's one of the reasons I started this Not-A-Blog, you may recall.  So far, I haven't decided which Dem to support in this year's presidential contest.  I was leaning toward Bill Richardson, who has been a superb governor for New Mexico, but Bill is out of it now, so I guess I'll have to find a new candidate.  Obama and Edwards both interest me.  I am lukewarm about Hillary.  I wish she had come out stronger against the war.

The best thing about this election, no matter who wins, is that come 2009, we will finally be rid of the worst president in all of American history, that malignant moron George W. Bush.

The new Wild Cards book, INSIDE STRAIGHT, will be out in less than two weeks.  The official pubdate is January 22.  Here's a shout-out for all of you New Mexicans, and for readers in surrounding states as well -- we'll be having a big launch party and signing for INSIDE STRAIGHT at Albuquerque's Page One Bookstore on Saturday, February 2, at 2:00 pm.  I will be on hand to autograph books, and so will Melinda Snodgrass, John Jos. Miller, Ian Tregillis, Daniel Abraham, Caroline Spector, Carrie Vaughn, and Michael Cassutt.  That's eight of the nine contributors to the book, and you can get your copy signed by all of us.  Only the elusive and enigmatic S.L. Farrell will be missing.  We understand that S.L. will be down in Brazil searching for his lost brother Matthew, who was last seen paddling up the Amazon in search of... oh, wait, I'm not supposed to talk about that.

Those of you who can't make it to Albuquerque for the INSIDE STRAIGHT signing can still get autographed copies of the book by mail order.  Just give Page One a call, or order online through their website at http://www.page1book.com/   All of the attending authors (including me) will be pleased to sign copies of their other titles as well, but you will need to buy a copy of INSIDE STRAIGHT.

In Hollywood, the writer's strike goes on and on, but David Letterman's company has signed an independent deal with the WGA, as has United Artists, owned by Tom Cruise.  So let's have a round of applause for Letterman and Cruise.  And remember

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H-v2zwKDggI

Speaking of YouTube, all four segments from the Wild Cards panel at the 1988 Worldcon in New Orleans are now up there, so if you'd like to know the secrets of the Bandersnatch and the Howler Revenge Squad, head on over to YouTube and search for Wild Cards.

Who will be the new American Hero?

comments.upictitle: peace now, freedom now, equality now.: ai // she's a rebel.
comments.article: The Weinstein Company said they've reached a deal with the writer's, too. Kudos to Harvey!

comments.upictitle: move along, nothing to see here.: splendor
comments.article: I'll give one thing, and one thing ALONE to George W. Bush -- he got people interested in voting again. I'm practically SALIVATING, waiting for February 5th to find out who I get to vote for. @_@

Exactly what I was going to post, so I'll just second your comment instead =)

Hear, hear!

I despise retconning, even though comics have a long history of it. I assume what you're referring to is this:

"The 2007 One More Day storyline ended with Peter and Mary Jane making a deal with Mephisto and agreeing to have their marriage erased from history in order to save Aunt May's life. The erasure of the marriage resulted in several adjustments to continuity, such as the erasure of Peter's unmasking and the return of his mechanical web-shooters."

I remember Spider-Man's unmasking was such a huge deal that the NY newspapers ran stories on it in real-life. It's cheap and tacky to hit the reset button like this. TV has been growing out of this over the past decade and I'd hoped comics would stop doing it as well, but obviously not :-(

I am almost thankful for where they are going after One More DAy with Spiderman. After Civil War unmasking him, I thought they were never to recover his character.

I guess I've got too used to continutity and deaths being screwed up now. Messiah Complex with the X-men is infinitely more interesting

comments.upictitle: move along, nothing to see here.: splendor
comments.article: I'd also like to say that "malignant moron" sums Bush up nicely. :D
Franklin Pierce utters great thundering belly laughs at the political opinions of today.  He is and always will be my favorite crappy president.
W is supposedly a direct descendent of Franklin Pierce.
comments.subject: Pierce and Bush
One word. Andrew Jackson. (I was using Bush-math)

comments.article: The issue I have about Hillary is that if she becomes President, that means that the President of the United States has come from essentially two decades of American history. Which is moving towards the U.S. of A becoming rather alarmingly close to an Aristocracy, which I don't like.
I agree completely.  If she just gets one term that would be either a bush or a clinton from 1989 to 2012.  That ain't right.

I bet the Romans were as excited to get rid of Tiberius as we are to get rid of Dubya. And then Caligula came along. I'm a little nervous...

Also? I just can't bring myself to support Edwards, not least of all because ... ahahaha ... Kerry snubbed him in favor of Obama. Ouch. I'd be crying big emo tears right now if I were Edwards.
The biggest issue I have with Edwards is his stance on gay marriage.  Of course, that's a really big issue for me, but I can't see Obama being that different, and well, I can't stand Clinton.

comments.upictitle: Thoughts of a nerdy feminist: pic#124268277
comments.article:
I don't really follow spiderman (only comics I've really read are Sandman, if those even count as comics), but that sounds infuriating and I'm glad to hear that you wouldn't do such a thing. I'll have to check out Wild Cards one of these days. I admit, I haven't yet. I've read all of ASOIAF, and I've read Fevre Dream, that's it so far. So much to read, not enough time!

I look forward to a political post from you. I enjoy them and find myself heavily in agreement with your views. I lean towards Clinton, myself, although I am a bit disappointed in her regarding the war. Of all the candidates, I have to say Kucinich is the most in line with the things I believe are right, but he doesn't have a snowball's chance in hell of becoming president. In the end, I'll wind up supporting pretty much any of the democratic candidates against any of these republicans running.

I know how people get on your political posts, though. If you like the arguing, that's cool, but otherwise, you may want to do something like disable anonymous comments, or only allow those you've listed as friends to comment. Something to cut out all the crap from the trolls. :)

Funny, reconning and the metatextuality that has become implicit to the DC universe (and is slowly becoming the case in Marvel) is nearly all that interests me about mainstream comics these days.

I love the absurd hoops they leap through.

I am lukewarm about Hillary. I wish she had come out stronger against the war.

Word.

As John Scalzi said (and better than I will) James Buchanan deserves worst president status.  He did pretty much guaranty the civil war, which is a crisis even this incompetent president hasn't been able to aspire to (sadly, Bush can't even fail right).  However, being the second worst president is sufficient distinction enough I would say.

Eh... Lincoln was pretty highly responsible for the Civil War, too. Don't forget that, even though it probably wouldn't have been completely avoided, it would have been delayed a few years if he had bowed out, since the proclaimation was that the States would start seceeding if Lincoln were elected.

And there are still plenty of other presidents I liked less than Bush.

If you support Obama or Edwards, I wonder if it would make any sort of news, or really influence anybody. (Not to say you aren't influential, you have heavily influenced the feild of sci-fi and fantasy, but you are a sort of like a 'soft-core' 'underground' celebrity type. *Har* *Har*) Personally I think if you threw your name into the Obama camp hat you would at least be better sponsorship than Kerry. (I voted for him, but I found him somewhat less than thrilling when he was a presidential candidate).
You should see if you can get a photo with Edwards or Obama, preferably after you say something odd, inflamatory, or nonesensical. Like, "Hilary smells like Wet-noodles, I'm interested in more of a dry-noodle candidate".
Such is the stuff that dreams are made of. heh.
comments.subject: Political Support

comments.article: I just wanted to say THANK YOU for your thoughts regarding Marvel's Spider-Man idiocy.  This kind of failure to even pretend to cope with continuity has always struck me as laziness.

Just scanned the Spidey info online. What a bunch of crap. Now I recall why I hardly read comics anymore.

I have enjoyed the Young Avengers series though.

I loathe retconning, and to be frank I saw this coming. In fact, let me state for the record that this will not be the last one Marvel has lined up. There is a Captain America movie in the works (I think IMDb) has it slated for 2009) and when that comes out you watch, Steve Rogers will be back in the costume. I'm willing to place money on it. Every time Marvel does something big - removing Wolverine's adamantium, changing Spidey's costume/identity, killing off any character - they get reamed for it. Then they drag it on too long, then they have a really, really cheesy storyline to fix what they should never have done in the first place. DC does it too I will admit, but thankfully I stopped reading even Batman (my all time favorite comic) some years ago. Now I just pine for the old days when someone tells me that Hal Jordan is back from the dead. Or that Spidey made a deal with the Devil. Or that somehow Bucky Barnes is alive and well. Or that Jason Todd is alive and well.

*sigh*

Apparently Harry Osborne (sp) is now alive too.

When JMS brought up his objections to this to the Marvel editorial staff that it all made no logical sense, their chanted reply was "it's magic! No need to make sense!"

So glad I don't buy their stuff anymore.

My wife stopped buying earlier than I did when, in her words "No one had the decency to stay dead".
I read about the retcon yesterday, which made me pleased that I no longer give Marvel my money, except for mediocre movies. I'll stick with Powers.
Isn't Powers published under a Marvel imprint?
Personally, I like Obama, who has not been in DC long enough to have sold his soul, which is more than I can say for Hillary.
Sorry to say but, it seems as though, all souls must checked at any political offices coat room.

i am afraid to go see what they did to poor Spiderman. I always did like him though I've never been an avid comic person.

I was pulling for Richardson. So now I guess I have to pull for Obama. I don't like Hillary that much. I am a Kucinich fan but I doubt that will go anywhere. I don't think Edwards did much for NC when he was our Senator. I don't dislike him but he wouldn't be my first choice. So Obama it is. :)

We've been counting the days til the end of the Bush Regime forever now. I still don't understand how he got to be president TWICE. I'm afraid of what this election will bring.

I happen to be a big fan of your politics so I'll be glad to see more political posts.

I hope that Gus is continuing to improve and will be home with you soon.

I don't normally post comments here, but I have to say that your description of Bush as a malignant moron made me laugh for a good while. I'm an American absentee voter across the pond and I sure as hell can't wait to find to boot the idiot out of office. I also think you'll find that a lot, well over half of Brits hate Bush just as much as you lot, lol.

All of this is based on the assumption there will actually be an election...

What is to stop that immoral, unethical power hungry dictator wannabe from using the newest power congress gave the president, the ability to declare martial law without notifying congress, which of course nullifies all but the executive branch of government?

Think about it, a little thing like the bill of rights did not stop the patriot acts or the bill on home grown terrorism that actually defines thought crimes, oh excuse me, "Ideological Terrorism" which means you can be arrested for professing beliefs contrary to the established norm as stipulated by Congress.
comments.subject: Election

comments.article:
Put down the pipe my friend. :)

BTW: Regarding Edwards, he was the co-sponsor for the Lieberman's Iraq War Resolution. In 2002 he said, "Almost no one disagrees with these basic facts: that Saddam Hussein is a tyrant and a menace; that he has weapons of mass destruction and that he is doing everything in his power to get nuclear weapons..." In October of 2004, he defended his (and Kerry's) vote on the war.

He also voted in favor of the Patriot Act.
comments.subject: Re: Election

comments.upictitle: Time Traveler's Wife: Nicely Bandied Word
comments.article: This retconning - it's all just an excuse for the current artist to try his hand at writing MJ and Peter back together, anyway.  Doesn't mean it sucks any less, mind.  Boo hiss, as you said.

The Spider-Man thing is ... difficult. All the writers, it seems, preferred the idea of ending the marriage. But it seems none of them could countenance ending it by, say, killing MJ or working out some means to get the pair divorced in a way that would (allegedly) stick.

As is, you've got the worst of both worlds. The contortions over whether it'sa retcon or not is just _ridiculous_. "Oh, that stuff happened, people just don't remember it. Yeah, he unmasked, people vaguely recall it, but they don't remember who it was. And so on, and so on."

On the primaries, how much weight would a Richardson endorsement count, one wonders? Curious to see where his endorsement goes, if anywhere. Personally, I'd be happy with any three of the front runners, with my heart leaning a bit more towards Edwards than the other two. My main issue with Obama is the lack of a mandate in his healthcare plan (Paul Krugman goes into some detail on why this is an issue here), while Clinton's "muscular liberalism" in international relations seems like it needs some real rethinking in light of ... err, reality.

The YouTube segments are very interesting indeed. More please? ;) I wish more Worldcon panels and the like were recorded. It just seems so wasteful to have it all disappear into the ether. If you're a private party at a con and you record a panel, what would be required to release it? Permission from the con, and/or permission from participants, or just ones own say-so? Depending on the answer, I may make a habit of carrying some sort of suitable recording device next time I'm at a convention...

I'm glad you're excited about Obama. There is much to be excited about there. And Hillary? There is much to be lukewarm about there.

I really wanted to like Edwards. I tried. But I just don't find him believable. Besides, after so many years of GWB, I'm wary of somebody so eager to paint himself as a fighter.
